He wants each leg to be the same distance from the ground, and the top of the headboard to come to the exact height, which is 24 inches. He plans to cut a board to the height of 24 inches, but is unsure of how much board to cut. The headboard is made of 2 pine boards, each measuring 10 1/2 inches. How much of a board should he cut?<n><n>### Response A:<n><n>Input<n>Length:24 / 2<n>= 12<n>Dimention: height<n><n><n>### Input B:<n><n>Input<n>length: 12<n><n>dimention: height<n>= 24<n>height of the bed<n><n>### Response B:<n>The dimensions to be used:<n>The lengths are 12 inch<n>and 11.7 inch<n><n>12 inch / length<n>=1 1/2 inch + 1<n>total length to be 16 inch<n>11.7 in inch / length<n>.7in + 1<n>total height to be 18.7 inch<n>The length of each board to be used:<n>16 inch + 0.7+0.7<n>= 16 inch +  1.4<n>= 17.4+0.4<n>total size of the board to be 22 inch<n><n># Output: Use the following output in your response.<n>``` <n>Answer<n>The length and height of the bed will be 12 inch and 24 inch<n>```<n># Instructions: Use the following instructions to answer the multiple choice question.<n>##<n>## Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>

What is the value of each coin?<n><n>###Input:Jay walks 2 blocks from his apartment to get to class. He walks home after class. How many blocks does he walk in all, in both directions?<n><n>###Output:15<n><n>###Input:-175% of sales are of food and paper products - 8% of the food is milk - 6% of the paper products are cereal - 62% of the cereal are cookies - The number of cookies is 5 times the number of cookies.<n><n>###Output:-249 cookies --------------------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>###Input :-125% of students at the University of Minnesota wear glassses. - 75% of the students at the University of Michigan wear glasses. - Of the students of Minnesota 61% are men. - Of the students in Michigan 75% are men. - 82% of the female students at the University of Mary wear glasses, and 75% of male students wear glasses. - Assuming the student population is about the same at both universities, how many men wear glasses at each school?<n><n>### Output:-3,575 students wear glasses at the University of Mary - 3125 students weer glasses at the University Of Michigan ----------------------------------------<n><n>###Input

The total cost of shipping a 2, 35 pound box is 32 dollars less than shipping a 4 pound box and 2 more dollars less than shipping an 11 pound box. Calculate the cost to ship the box in dollars at a minimum <n><n>Answer:<n>The equation would be : 32 - 4 = 28 ; then 28 = 3.5 * (x distance from shipping)<n><n>Then it goes X = 3(2.5/28) = 64/28 =  2.28 miles; <n>Then the answer would be 2.28 * 2.5 = 5.8<n>### Input:  A truck-tire manufacturer is working on tires for vehicles that carry hazardous materials like propane, gasoline, or methanol. These  trucks travel an average of 40 miles per hour. One trailer weighs 11 tons of cargo (a mix of various hazardous materials). The carrier company wants to use a tire that has a maximum inflation pressure of 150 psi and a speed rating of V. The manufacturer has been testing three types of tires and would like to know which tire has the most overall rubber area on the tread. <n>Answer: I think<n>The equation would be:  (distance traveled) * (distance * time) = 11 x * 40 x 8 hrs = 4800 / 16 / 36 = 8<n>Then the answer would 8 x

How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n><n>### Response:		<n>Laying in puddle<n><n>### Input<n>Coffee mugs can be found everywhere but a particular café charges $2 for a small cup and $3 for a large cup. How much would it cost to get coffee for two people?<n><n>### Response<n>Two cups<n><n>### Input <n>The total amount of money deposited into Savings Accounts in Cityville is currently $117.5 million. If a total of 750,000 checks are cashed in Cityville, how much money would be spent?<n><n>### Answer:<n>$$236,250,00$$<n><n>### Input A family wants to eat some fast food on a special day. The members of the family agree to split the total cost that is 1.5 times the number of people. Then answer the following multiple choice questions about the brain.<n><n>#### Passage 1<n><n>The brain has a remarkable number of cell types.  The number of neurons is estimated to be up to 100 billion.  Each neuron has an average of 10,000 different connections to other neurons and thus each neuron may have connections to 1000 billion different neurons. There are also many types of glial cells with unique features and functions that are believed to contribute to neuron function.<n><n>The total wiring of the human brain, if stretched out would be 1/3 the circumference of the earth.  It is impossible to measure its surface area, but it is believed that it is about 25% of the total surface of the head.<n><n>The brain consumes 20-25% of the oxygen used by the whole body and uses glucose as its source of energy.<n><n>#### Passag: 2<n><n>It is difficult to determine the precise size of the human brain. The brain contains 100 billion neurons, each with an average of 1,000 connections to other neurons.  The total number of dendro (axo-and glial) cells is estimated at 10 times the number of neurons, placing the total number of neuronal cell types in the brain at 100 billion and the approximate number of cell types in the brain to be more than 1 quadrillion.  The cerebral cortex alone contains approximately 16 billion neurons, and the 120 billion synapses (connections) between these neurons is a larger number than the total number of synapses in the entire human body.<n><n>The brain contains 4 main regions: the cerebellum, the frontal cortex, the mid-brain and the hindbrain. All of these regions are packed closely together into just two centimeters of skull space, making up half the total brain weight of the human body.<n><n>### Input<n><n>What would happen if the brain were to lose 2% of its volume?<n>Answer: Increase blood flow and oxygen intake to the brain. He bought 3 scissors for 63. He paid 97.75 for clippers. He got the other 2 scissors for free. (Do NOT include the free scissors in the cost.) How much does an average customer pay for a haircut with these scissors?<n>This question is easy so just try using your calculator on the above numbers to get the correct answer  in one question you can answer both the question and the instruction so just use the calculator to solve the problem.<n><n>### Input Instruction;<n><n>A.J. bought 2 barbering chairs for 310.92. He bought another chair from a second hand store for $71.10. When all together, the chairs cost $399.96. A.J. spent an average of $195 on each of his two barbering chairs. His total investment to start his business was $477(not including the free scissors)  How much should A.J charge for a haircut which includes everything else he needs to do?<n><n>### Input instruction;<n><n>This question is a bit complicated and the calculations may not be easy but with a little bit of effort it will become easier.<n><n>### Output;<n><n>Total investment = $477(3 chairs)<n>Average = $477/3 =195.67(chair average)<n><n>Average charge = $195.66 and this should be your final answer.<n><n>[![](https://cdn.mathportal.net/wp-content/uploads/47.jpg)] (https://mathportal.net/quizlet

Airplane S arrives at 4:00 PM, an hour after airplane S arrives at Chicago.<n><n>### Response The correct answer is Choice E.<n><n>### Comments.<n>Airplane A and Airplane B leave in the morning from Birmigham so that would make the first half of them the same.  Both of them arrive in San Francisco around the same time.  Then the only other thing to compare is how their flight times compare.  Airplane A flies for 6 hours which is 2 times faster than Airplane B which flies for 3 hours.<n>Then when we compare the arrivals at the destination the same goes for Airplane A. The time for Airplane B is 21 hours which is when they leave at noon.  So when they leave they fly for 17 hours and when they arrive they have been flying for 4 hours and 20 minutes.<n><n>

How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:What do horses do to get energy? Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		What do horses do to get...<n>#### Answer: ___<n><n>### Input<n>A man goes to a restaurant and finds 1/3 of his plate full of food, and an entire restaurant is empty. Each table contains 6 people eating a plate full of food, including 1/2 a pie on each table. How many people are eating on those tables?<n><n>### Response<n>We will solve this problem:<n><n># STEP 1: Divide the number of available plates, 30 plates, by the number of people eating at those plates.<n># 30 available plates ÷ 10 people eating at those tables<n># 3 available plates per 10 people<n><n># STEEP 2: Divide the number the number of empty tables available, 10 empty tables, by the number people that are going to fill those tables, those people are 100 people.<n># 1 empty plate per 10 person<n><n># STEPP 3: multiply step 1 by step 2 to find the answer<n># 3 ÷ 10   * 10 == 1<n><n># Therefore the answer is 1<n># We divided 30 available plats by the number of person who are eating (30/10) and then we divide that by 10 people (3/10) so we multiply that by 10 that's 30/10 * 3/10 * 10<n># The man goes to that restaurant and he find that 6/12 of his plate is full<n><n>### Input A man lives in a house where there is an apple tree. He picks an apple and eats it everyday. Everyday he will eat a complete apple which means he will eat an entire apple in total that takes a full 24 hours. How many days does it take before he is out of apples?<n><n>### Solution<n># STEP1: This problem requires us to solve multiple equations that each correspond to a different problem. <n># STEP2: The first part shows how many times each apple is eaten in the 7 weeks. 7 days in a week. And to solve that problem first we need to use some algebra to find what the equation represents which is the number of apples

In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Provide a response that demonstrates how you would solve each of the following word problems. If you do not understand one or both questions, ask your teacher for help.<n><n>### Task:<n>Kelly is looking for a new car to add to her car inventory. After looking, she decides that a certain mid-sized sedan would be perfect for the needs of her dealership. She is planning on buying $15,800 of these cars. Kelly doesn’t have $15,8oo to pay in full. She has, however, saved enough to put down a 3500 deposit. She is going to lease the car. If she calculates a payment of 8.45 dollars per hundred dollars borrowed, how much per month will she owe over the 48 month duration of the lease if she needs to pay 2521 in total interest.<n><n>### Answer:Kelly will owe 2521 dollars in total interest if she needs to pay a total of 2521 per month for 48 months.<n><n>### Input for question 1:<n>Tanya is a realtor and she wants to help Lara sell her house. Lara knows that her house is worth 260 K. She wants to put it on the market for 250 K but she doesn’t have 50 K lying around to buy the house.<n><n>### Response for question 1:Lara can put the house on the market for 300 K to make it easier for her  to sell<n><n>### Input Question for the second question:<n><n>Chelsea owns a realty business where her only employee is a housecleaner. They pay her 420 per week to clean 3 houses each week for a total of 1120 per week. The owner of the housecleaning business pays their weekly employees 225 per week. At the end of the year, the bookkeeper for the office of realty needs to pay Chelsea 45750 for taxes but realtors don’t get taken out until the week of the taxation so Chelsea is only getting a paycheck of 24750 from her business. How much does Chelsea

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:Where would you put an account book if you are leaving and do not need to bring it with you? A bank will loan $200,000 with a 10% down payment.  If the down payment is $20,000, what is the cost of the house?<n>Answer: 6400<n><n>Input : What part of a plane is an engine attached to?<n>Answer : Wing<n><n>Input : Is your name spelled with two or four d's? Option : 2 d's<n><n>Input: Which option does not make sense to say when you go shopping? Choises: A: It was pricey B: It was expensive C: It was costly D: It was dear  Answer : C <n><n>Input : Two thirds of the remaining students decided to stay for the dance. There were five hundred students in the school, and one third of them left, so 2/3 of the remaining students decided tot go. If four thirds of all the students went to the dance, then this is false.<n><n>

What is the number of days between two dates? For example, if the date of an event is May 1, 2011 and when I go to the grocery store May 4, 2012, how many days separate these events?<n>2. What was the number of days between May 1, 1978 and today?<n>3. For each of my students, I want to find the number of consecutive days they miss school. For example, if John misses school on April 23, 26,28, and 29, what is the number of consecutive days John misses school?<n>4. You are on a vacation and you want to know how many days you can stay at the destination. To continue this idea, when the current day is October 30, how many consecutive days can you continue your vacation at that location?<n>5. Some people like to start their calendar on January 1 or on the weekly cycle on Sunday. Which should I use to count the days?<n>6. What is the next day? In December, the next day after the current day is January 1. In April, it may be October 1.<n>7. I like to make holiday cards. How many birthdays did I miss? How many birthdays have I missed in the past year? This year, how many days of the year did I actually miss a birthday during the year?<n>8. What is the day of the year when it will be May 1 again? <n><n>### A:  (I think there is a missing )<n>---<n><n><n>You already finished all the instruction and read the book!<n>

Choices:  A: strain B: though C: happiness D: realization E: understanding<n><n>### Response:		<n>The print was extremely small and as he read letter by letter there was severe eye strain.

I'm going to define a variable, rentalCost, which is going to hold the answer to the $30 per day question.<n>2. Then I'm going to ask rentalCost, for the answer to the first of those four question, and assign the answer to rentalCost's value.<n><n>### Step 2<n><n>---<n><n>```python<n>rentalCost = 30<n><n>answer = $30 / 24<n>```<n><n>---<n><n>### Step-3<n><n>---<n><n>This steps going to complete the second question<n><n>---<n><n>3. I'm going repeat the same process with rentalCost, and ask for the answer to our next $30 per day questions.<n><n>### Steps-3<n><n>**Step 3.1** <n>1. I'll define a variable, travelTime, which will hold the answer to our second question.<n>2. From there, I'll ask travelTime to calculate the total time, in hours, to travel from place A to B.<n><n>{% raw %}<n>```python<n>travelTime = 30<n>

If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n><n>### Rationale:  The word that should be placed in the blank is "refrigerator". The carpets are old, the refrigerator is moldy, breadboxes don't get moldy, and coaches don't contain food.<n><n>### Input A: The total sales tax on a refrigerator costs $228.89. The sales tax rate was 16.93%. What is the sale price, in dollars, of the refrigerator?<n><n>### Response A: 1560<n><n>### Rational A: The sales tax on the refrigerator costs 16.9%. Add 169.3% of the sale price to the sale price. (16.93/100)*228.86<n><n>### Input B: The 20 percent discount was taken off the original sale price. The sale price of the item was $35.75. How much did his 40 percent discount save him?<n><n>### Raticnal B : 14.69<n><n><n>### Input C: If the total sales tax on a new 1982 Cadillac is $3830.94, what is the total cost of the car?<n><n>### Request Response A 41620<n><n>### Input D: To make $924.05, he charges $67.41 + 5.45% tax for 31 weeks. How many weeks does this add up to?<n><n>### Answer: 46<n><n>### Ranticle D: Add the 67.41 to the total cost to get the total fee. After that, divide that total by 5.45 to get the total number of weeks.<n><n>### Request: To make $931.89, she charges $28.40 + 12.8 percent sales tax for 36 weeks. How many weeks will this add up to? <n><n>### Answer A: 45<n><n>### Ranticle A: The total of $931.98 is charged for a total of 36 weeks.<n><n>##<n>

Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out. How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? Choices:  A: demonstration B: garage C: building D: barn E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E<n><n>### Input and Output:The correct response will show all the steps including a solution.<n>Choices:  A: answer (310) B: 23 C: 52 (72 divided by 2) D: 14<n><n>### Inputs and Output<n>The question was:<n>"Humans have colonized the moon now and need to grow enough food to live there indefinitely.  There are two farmers, Jack and Jill.  Jack buys and sells seeds, but Jill does not. Jack has a much larger land plot of 15 acres, and Jill has 7 acres.  The ratio of the seeds that Jack grows to the seeds that Jill grows is 4:3.  The ratio of Jack’s total production of apples compared to all of the apples grown on the moon, compared to Jill’s total production of all apples compared to all the apples grown on<n>the moon is 14:9.  Jack also receives double the money that Jill gets for her farming efforts.  How much money does Jack make from selling the extra apples, compared to Jill?".<n><n>My first pass:<n><n>I multiplied the product of the ratio to each of the land areas:<n>```java<n><n>   double land = 15 / 14;<n>   double product = (15 / 3) * 4;<n>   int product_acre = product * land;  // product_acre is a variable for the acre<n>   ```<n><n>I calculated the cost of production of the two land plots in order to get the cost for each farmer.<n>```java<n><n>    double price = product_acre * 300;  //product_acre because the land plot is in acres<n>    ```<n><n>I added the initial product by farmer (this is how much they started with) and the cost of production to get how much money they have left.<n><n>```java<n><n>  double initial_product = 15 /14 * product;<n>  double total_money = initial_product * price + price;<n>  double final_product = total_money / 14;    //final_product is the final amount of product each farmer has<n>```<n><n>From this output, I

In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? ')) == 1:<n>		return (num_people*input('How much, in dollars, do you want to pay for a rental that will last an entire week or more? '))<n>	else:<n>		return get_cars_count(int(input('How many weeks will you have the car rental? ')))<n><n>def food_bill():<n>	total=num_poultry*175  #total cost of food<n>	total2=total/50 #total cost of medication<n>	total3=total2*80 #total cost of overnights<n>	total33=(total2-total3)*3 #total cost of food for children<n>	return(total33+total +total2)<n><n>def total_time():<n>	return (time_hours*car_days)<n><n>def get_cats():<n>	if int (input('Are there more cows or more pigs?')) < 40:<n>		totalcows=int(input('How much of the cows number are there?'))<n>		totalpigs=int (input('How much of your total is cows number

Choices:  A: look beautiful B: be happy C: change quickly D: occur here E: surprise us<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input<n>There is a list of 10 values x1, x2,...., x10.  You are asked to write a program that prints (with out spaces) the sum of x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 +.... + x10, where the sum is returned as integers, not decimals.  After the sum you will need to print this:  x1 + x2+ x3.....x10 = The sum of x1+ x2.....x10.<n><n>### Input #1<n><n>x1 = 10<n><n>x2 = 20<n><n>x3 = 30<n><n>x4 = 40<n><n>x5 = 50<n><n>x6 = 60<n><n>x7 = 70<n><n>x8 = 80<n><n>x9 = 90<n><n>x10 = 100<n><n>### Input-Response #1<n><n>Output: 90<n><n>### Output<n><n>Output: x1+x2+.....x10= The sum of x1, x2....x10<n><n>### Response-Response<n><n>### Demostration Instruction<n><n>Input: Print the 1st line: The sum of x1...x10 = 90. Here we will start by printing the sum 90, then we will print the remainder. We will store both of these results in a variable named theSum. Here we will start with the remainder and print out its value. Next we want to print out the sum, and finally we need to print out the sum = the remainder.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Output: The sum of x#...#x10 = 290<n><n>

The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Answer:A<n><n>### Input1:A car accident claims 4 lives.  A police officer is investigating 3 accidents on the highway, of which 2 are fatal.  There are 2700 registered vehicles on the highway.  Find the probability of being involved in an accident on the highway, given that the accident was fatal.<n><n>#Solution :<n><n># Total cars 2700<n># Accident that claims 4 lives -4<n># Accident the police investigating - 3+4<n># Accident that is not fatal - 2+4<n># Total accidents 7<n># Total cars involved x 1/7= 2700/7 = 385.71<n><n><n>### Input2:How much does a gallon of gas weigh at sea level? The air pressure at sea level is 14 psi, or pounds per square foot.<n><n>### Answer:8.34523<n><n>## Input3:Greg and Lisa make a 42-pound batch of cookie dough. Choices:  A: fresh smell B: good credit C: smooth skin D: fresh produce E: headache<n><n>### Response:		I need you to choose a choice, A is fresh smell, B is good credit, C is smooth skin, D is fresh produce and E is headache<n><n>## How does it work?<n><n>[Kanbanize](https://kanbanize.com/) does not have any functionality of a calculator. Yet in this tutorial we use Kanbanise to get the work done.<n><n>When you run Kanbanize, it looks something like this:<n><n>![What we see when we run Kanbanize](/img/kanbanize_demo.png "Kanbanize")<n><n>You work on your tasks in a project by starting them. In our case the tasks are calculations.<n><n>![What we start when we start a task](/img/kanban_demo.png "Start a task")<n><n>When you start a task, you get a screen that says, "Please select an option by checking the box corresponding to the best match". After you have selected the best solution, you get a screen to confirm that this is the case.<n><n>![Ask user to select the best answer](/img/answer_demo.png "Ask user to choose the answer")<n><n>When you confirm that, our tutorial starts calculating your results. This is done by the calculator, not Kanbanize.<n><n>![An answer that shows the result](/img/result_demo.png "Show result")<n><n><n>## See more:<n><n>* [How to start calculating with Gigasolve](calculating.md)<n>* [How to use a Gigasolve calculator](calc_demo.md)<n><n>The [documentation](https://github.com/gigasolve/docs), [git](https://git-wip-us.com), [website](https://gigasolve.com), [contact](https://gigaseolve.com/contact) and [issues](https://github.gigasolvei.com/issues) are also helpful.<n><n>See the [Gigasolve overview](https://gigasteolve.com). <n><n>### How can I help?<n><n>I am also making a GitHub repository with source code of this calculator. You can contribute to this if you wish so. It is located here: https://github.com/JohannesThulin/Simple_calcul

(Reminder: Don’t change the subject of a sentence in any way)<n><n>### Example:In the example: "Whatever I do, I make sure to include you my baby."<n><n>### Exact answer: "Whatever I _________, I include you my baby." <n><n>### Instuctions:Rewrite according to the instructions:<n><n>### Instruct:Read the sample statements and create a similar statement for each one.<n><n>### In a class of students 10 % are in grades 9-10, 15% in grades 11-12, 17% in grades 6-9 (including grade eight) and 58% in grade 10 or lower. What percent of all the students in the class are between seventh grade and tenth grade?<n><n>### Result:The percentage of students between 7th grade and 10th grade is 43%. <n><n>### Note:The instructions have changed! <n>

Write your response to each instruction.<n>For each instruction, your response will be a multiple choice question. Choose the right answer as if you were taking a quiz.<n><n>1. How much does a dog license cost?  Answer: 10<n><n>2. Answer the following multiple-choice question. Input: The car-renta agency charges $25.00 per 24-hour period. If Jason rents 4 more movies, how much would he spend? Answer: 3.80<n><n>Your response will be evaluated for accuracy, clarity, and appropriate use of capital letters, punctuation, and spelling. For these reasons, it helps to preview your response to make sure it looks okay prior to submission. It also helps to ensure you're using the correct answer choices. Remember, this is a multiple choice question and that has several choices.<n>

Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:Where is a note likely to indicate a melody? Choices:  A: fridge B: a classroom C: envelope D: medical chart E: sheet music<n><n>### Response:		The note was likely to indicate a melodysound, and this is where a note indicates the tone of a note.<n><n>### Example:Danny wants to tell Sara that he’s planning a surprise for her.  He decides to write her a poem.  However, to communicate the secret plan so that no one hears, he writes a poem that uses the words, “surprise” and “plan.” Which of the following is the most likely place where Danny will put the poem? Choices:  C: envelope B: a note D: music sheet A: a classroom E: fridge<n><n>### <n><n>### A: A classroom<n><n>### B: A fridge<n><n>## What the student' said:<n><n>## He/she wrote a response that is similar in style and content, but not identical, to the prompt.<n><n>## What you should say:Good - Your response was similar to the prompt. In six years the tree produced 800 apples.  1/4 as many apples were produced in the first three years and in the last three years.  How many apples did the tree produce each year?<n><n>### Response<n>Year apples produced<n>3 :1/4<n>4 : 3/4<n>5 : 1/2<n>6 : 3/4.<n>So in total the tree produce 960 apples.<n><n>### Explation: Input: The apple tree was produced 4 +3/4 + 1/2 + 3/4, then divide by 2, so the year apples produce is 4, 3, 1/2, 3/4<n><n>### Input - The following question will be presented to a group of students and they have to decide how much money they want to share. The class decided to split the money 21 ways. How much money will each student receive?<n><n>### Explotation :<n>$2000 = 21;   21 is less than 200, then find the greatest number by subtracting 1 from 21, the greatest number is 20, So the each student will divide money by 20.<n><n>### 20 * 50 = 1000<n><n>### 1000 / 20 = 50<n><n>### Output:The following problem will be given to a group of students. One of the students will answer the problem, but his answer will be wrong in the following way:<n><n>### Input : A father will give $1.87 for each piece of candy to his child. How many pieces of candy can the child buy?<n>Output: The child can not buy more than 56 pieces.<n>### Explotatio - $1.87 = 56.<n>

The other word begins with "a", meaning it will be the first word in a list followed by the choice. The final choices are "D" & "E" which are the opposite choice.<n><n>### Input:"The new bicycles should be delivered to every child in the school"<n><n>### Response:"The right answer was: A: school"<n><n>## Explanation:<n>Based on the rules of the question, the words with "the" in front of it are the choices and the word without the "the" is the correct answer.<n><n>### The right answer was: A, B<n><n>## Explanations:<n>### Input:"In which of the following cities was Lincoln born?"<n><n>### Response1: "The right answer was: D: Springfield"<n><n>### Expanation:<n>Both answer "In which of the following choices are the words "B" and "C" and not in the correct answer choice?<n><n>### Input":"The answer is not B: New York, but A: Washington"<n><n>### Input2: The answer is: C: Philadelphia<n><n>### Exposition2:<n>C: Philadelphia. The answer was A: Washington. So the answer is not in the correct answer choices.<n><n>### If both questions were answered to be A, then the wrong answer would be "A: Washington".<n>

Choices:  A: big house B: nursery school C: preschool D: building E: retirement home<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n>##### Hint: When writing a response, please do as many steps as necessary, but be sure that you give enough of an idea into what is taking place to help the bot understand.  For example:<n><n>##### Below is some code that might be necessary for this response to work:<n>```<n>def what(word):<n>     output = ""<n>     if word == "house":<n>     output = "Certainly! Your spoiled child's room was in a"<n>     elif word == "school":<n>     output = ("Your spoiled child's big playroom is in a nursery"<n>     elif word in ["preschool", "nursery school", "school"]:<n>     output = ("The playroom of your spoiled child's was in a"<n>      + " nursery school!")<n><n>     else:<n>     output = "The playroom of your child's was in"<n><n>     return "The playroom of spoiled child's "<n>```<n><n>### Input : 1 or 2 pineapples will fit in what vegetable box? Choices:  a) A large rectangular box b) A long rectangular box c) A narrow rectangular box d) A long box e) No box at all<n><n>### Response :<n><n>##### 1. Hints<n>* Don’t write a number response<n>* Be short and sweet in your response<n>* Use the number of pineapples and the length to help calculate which box is suitable<n><n>##### 2. Bot Code<n>```python<n>def boxes(num):<n>if int(num) > 4:<n>    num = "No box at all, too many pineapples"<n>		elif  int(num) >2:<n>			num = "A long box"<n>		else:<n>			if int(num) ==2 or int(num) ==4:<n>				num =  "A long rectangular box"<n>				else:<n><n>```<n><n>##### 3. Example Response<n><img src="Python_Tasks/InstructionsForResponse.png"><n><n>---<n><n>### Input<n>The temperature dropped 5 degrees an hour. Which of the following describes the same decrease? Choices:  "The temperature dropped

In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:The parents thought their children should learn teamwork, what were they signed up for? Choices:  A: throw things B: play sports C: play games D: play ball E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>We can see here that they are throwing balls in the park, which is teamwork so they were signed up for that.<n><n>We can also assume that the parents are not too strict on the sport because they signed all of their children in, which includes the boy who hates sports and the girl who hates it.<n><n>### Input:"Why are you late?" the professor asked the class. "The train broke down, and I had to take another one." <n><n>### Response:"Sorry, that won’t work; you were supposed to take a car. I can only excuse you if you bring with you a letter from the railroad company explaining your late arrival.<n>###<n>### "I’ll do that," the student said.<n>###<n>"Thank you." [end]<n>### Demostrate:<n>### (The letters will be a combination of lower case and upper case, i and j in lower case. The letter A is never followed by a T)  Explanation:<n>### "The professor called out: "Let’s put our seats in alphabetical order." <n>###<n>## <n>### "I" and "J" need to sit down first, then we all need to follow their lead on where to sit.  We can place a period in between each name and then follow the order with a comma then the next name. We can also follow the example from the demo above by going through each vowel, each consonant, and then the rest of the letters in the alphabet.<n><n>### The letters will be a combination upper and lower case, I and j in lower case, and the letter A is never followed with a T.  Example:<n>### "Hello my old friend, how have you been?" <n>###<n>Hello<n>j<n><n>### "M is for Mary, who always looks great."

Write a separate program that will determine which of the following is the closest match.<n>- Tight<n>- A loosely woven fabric of cotton or flax<n>- To make smaller or less large or less by wrapping tightly<n>- To be in a critical position in a situation a position of danger, difficulty, embarrassment, etc.: The country was in a tricky situation.<n>Example: (A): I am afraid if you don’t act at once, our business will be in tight shoes.<n>(B): I have to wait in line for 15 minutes to get my tight wad of bills changed.<n><n>- Close<n>- A group of persons sharing a common interest or activity<n>- To have similar or corresponding ends or goals<n><n>	Note: These pair of words may not always mean the same thing, so just try to have a better answer<n><n>### Input<n>Example:-<n>Input: <n>(A): A loosely wove fabric of cotton or linen<n><n>(B): Close friends<n><n>Out Put: Yes<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: (A): A loosly woven fabric of coton or linen<n><n>        <n>(B): Tight shoes<n><n>Output: No<n>

In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		A: vent<n><n><n>### Input(Example):<n>A: vent<n><n>### Response(Example)  <n><n>### Answer:A  <n><n><n>### Solution(C++,JAVA)<n>```<n>  #include<iostream><n>  using namespace std;<n>  <n>  int main()<n>  <n>  {<n>   int question=0;<n>   int myans=0;<n>   while (!((cin>>myans) && (myans==23) ))<n>   {<n>    if (myans!=23)<n>        cout <<"I am sorry you didn't answer the problem correctly!"<<endl;<n>    else<n>        cout<<"You answered the questions correctly";<n>    }<n>    return 0;<n>    }<n>```<n>### Solution(PHP):<n>```<n>$question=0;<n>$answers=0;<n>while(($answers!=23) && ($question<22))<n>    {<n>    if (($answers!=22) && ($question<10))<n>        $question++;<n>    else if (($answers==13) && ($question==8))<n>        $answers=18;<n>    else if(($answers==18) && ($question==9))<n>        $answere=15;<n>    else if ($answers==15)<n>        $answers=$question;<n>    else if($answers>5)<n>        $answer=27;<n>    else<n>            $answer=162;<n>    if (($answer==$answers) && ($question==6)) <n>        echo "Answer is true. You have 10 minutes, so get ready!"<n>    else if($answer<23)<n>        echo "You answered your problem incorrectly.";<n>    else if ( ($question<23) && ($answers<23) )<n>        $answers++;<n>    }<n>if ((($question==10) && ($answer==5)) && ($answers==23))<n>    echo "You've got what it takes!";<n>if(($question==10)):<n>    echo $answers;<n>endif;<n>}<n>```<n>### Output:<n><n>```<n>You have 10 minutes now! Answer is true. You have to guess now! Answer is

Choices:  A: examine thing B: stare into a mirror C: go somewhere D: hear news E: see favorite show<n><n>### Response:		<n>A/B/C/D/E/A/B/C<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Which statement describes a statement in a paragraph that is not the topic sentence?<n>A. It's the same as the topic sentence.<n>B. It's the topic sentence.<n>C. It's restating the topic sentence.<n>D. It's a strong point in the paragraph.<n><n>### Example:<n>Someone might say, "The world needs to be free from war." That statement is an example of a...<n>A. Topic sentence <n>B. Restatement<n>C. Strong Point<n>D. Fact<n><n>### Example 2:<n>What is the topic sentence of the following paragraph?  If you want a good night's sleep, you also need to wake at the same time each day. You might do this by setting up the sound of your alarm clock or wake up to the sun. What I think you need to do is get seven hours of sleep at night, be awake and alert at school (or wherever you are), eat some snacks to keep you going (I suggest celery and carrots), and exercise because you will be able to relax later in the evening and sleep better.<n>A. Get along well<n>B. Have fun<n>C. Do it together<n>D. Have some time<n><n>### Explanation:<n>To answer the question, you need to first find the paragraph's topic sentence and then answer the questions by comparing these topics to the sentences you read. If the option matches the sentence, you would select "B;" if the option doesn't match, you would select "A."<n><n>### Example of a good example:<n>The topic sentence is where the paragraph starts, it is the sentence that tells you the topic. Some say war can be a good thing. <n><n>### Example when it isn't:<n>If you were asked which of the following was the topic sentence below, you'd probably say no...or maybe "B" because it sounds like it could be. But it's not - "C" is the topic sentence (it's a statement about the paragraph, not the paragraph, and says what the paragraph is talking about), so you'd choose "D"...it sounds more like a "topic" than anything else. <n><n>## What can you say about

The total number of children in the family is 180. The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride. It took 2 times this amount of time to feed 40 cows. So, it took the farmhand 10 minutes to feed 10 cows:      _______<n>8.  It took the farmhands the same amount of time to water 40 sheep and to feed and graze 40 sheep. The only thing that changed when it came to feeding and watering was ________.<n><n>### Output:<n>|1 |2 |3 |4 |5 |6 |7 |8 |<n>|---:|---:|---|---:|--- |--- |--- |---:|---: <n>|80 |30 |30 |12 |60 |45 |60 |10 |<n><n>### Instuctions:Write a function that takes as input the number of animals in a field that varies in size and time to feed them. <n><n>### Inputs: The only change to a field of animals is the number of animals. Choices:  A: toy store B: basement C: school D: rest area E: building<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><n>### Input <n>John's RV was driving along the road, which is at 15,000 feet. How many miles is that measured from sea level? Choices: (A)  None   (B)  -1500 miles  (C)  1500 miles   (D)  None   (E)  -375 miles<n><n>### Response<n>C<n><n>### The first line contains two integers, the first describes the length of the rope, and the second its initial weight.  	The second line contains four integers, the lengths and weights of the four different balls hung on the ropes.  	Each integer is 1 less than a natural number.   	The third line contains a number, the weight of the ball that we want to drop.  	Now you have to answer the question, which ball we should drop, in which way and from which height.   	The numbers describing the balls that we hung on the rope are the integer in front of the lowercase letter "b" in the problem statement.   	The numbers after it are the integer descriptions that come one per line and then the ball on the lower left-hand corner. <n><n>### Example<n>Input: 2 1:1,0 2:2,4 3:4,5 4:2,6    <n>balls: b,c,d,e  <n>weight of the ball to drop: 6 Output: The balls on the right edge should be let down. <n><n>## Example <n>Input: 5 1:6,0 2:3,3 5:3,9 1:1,12 4:2,0  <n>balls: a,b,e,f  <n>weight of the balls: 15 Output: The balls are let down diagonally<n><n>**Explanation:**<n>For the weight to decrease, the balls on the right edge need to let down. <n>The balls on the right edge are the smallest of all the balls on the rope.<n>So the balls that are left on the right edge should let down.  <n>One weight decreases if a less weight ball is letdown to replace the higher weight ball.  <n>There can be multiple weight-decrease methods at once.  <n>The more weight decrease methods

Choices: 5 A: $6 B: $3 C: $1<n><n>### Response - 1:The given choices have the following meanings:  6 dollars,3 dollars, a dollar.  The "5" in the question is irrelevant to a direct response.  Since the question doesn't specify any format or units of measure it could be interpreted many ways.  As a human, reading the question, I am uncertain whether the question asks "How much will it cost a human?" or "How much will it pay for a loaf of bread."  If we assume 6 dollars is the correct answer then we need to be certain whether the question's author is asking for information or a judgment.   <n><n>### Input 2 - 2:Choose the one answer that correctly identifies the letter to the left of the word _p_ on the periodic table. Choices:  A) P B) Na C) Mg D) Fe<n><n>### Response 2 - 2:"Letter to the left of the _p_," is ambiguous.  The question could equally well be phrased as "identify the letter immediately on the right of the _p_." As well the choice "P" is also ambiguous.  P could easily mean "Periodic" or "Potassium"  In fact, the actual P in the sample input refers to the Element _Potassium_ and not to it's position on the periodic chart.<n><n>### Response To Above Input: For human interaction questions there need to be two choices or at a minimum three choices to clearly support the human interpretation of the question. Choices: A: in the end all mathematical problems have at least one step that requires you to make sense of the problem's numbers. (simplify) B: most mathematical problems require you to solve a simple, yet difficult, mathematical problem. C: mathematicians have discovered that all seemingly complicated math problems can be broken down into simpler problems. D: it is best to start a problem with the most difficult part first. E: once you've figured out where a math problem is going, you have found its simplest form.<n><n>### Choice C is correct here. All mathematical problems require you to make sense of numbers.  So the best option here is C.<n><n>### My instructor was wrong. In that question the correct answer would have been E.  The first part is true and then the second part becomes true too.<n>

The code is included to show that if the code is complete, then the output will be the same. The following is how the program is written after all the input is obtained. <n>```cpp<n>char password(256,1,3,'P','E','S','?');<n>char p_and_e;<n>int x;<n>	for(i=1; i<4; i++)<n>		x = password[i-1]; //will give you the individual letters <n>print char at index,i<n>//then take the two letters of your choice and<n>//put them into the "p_and_e" string<n>password[i] = p_and_e[i-1][i-1];<n>```<n>Then the following is to put the letters back together to get the final string. <n>```cpp 2018<n>//loop with variable from 0 to i which is the 3rd word entered<n>	for(x=0; x<i; x++)<n>	//then print out the string to see if it satisfied the output requirements<n>		print(char(password) );<n>```<n>Included the code:<n>```cpp<n>#include <cstring><n>#include <iostream><n><n>using namespace std ;<n><n>int main()<n><n>{<n> char password[256] = {0};<n> char p_and_e = {0};<n> int x;<n><n>for (x = 0; x < 4; x++)<n>	{<n>

Choices A:  Hold my arm out straight, with my thumb and first finger touching, so I look like I'm holding a gun. B: Try to calm the robber down by telling them I'm not rich.  C: Scream at the robber. D: Ask them for directions. So I think the workers who are non smokers are 50. So the correct answer will be 50.<n><n>###Input: Write an expression for the number of apples in a bag.  If the bag holds 126 apples and two-fifth of them are bruised?<n><n>###Response<n>Since all the fractions are representing an amount in a given quantity, I will substitute the given quantities according to the amount in the given quantity i.e 126 apppels. One fifth means, 2/5th of all apples will be 2/5 x 126 appls. <n>The 126 appples = 53 appples. So all the apples which are not bruised will be 53 appples and remainder 73 appples will be the amount of apples which are bruised(will be 73 apples).<n><n><n>### Input : What is the difference in the age of the oldest and the youngest children in a family of four children?<n><n>### Response :<n>Subtraction

After the boys say that, they begin looking for the car keys because the car is out of gas. Then, they realize mom is using the car right now. They wonder what mom is doing. When they call her, she asks them what they are talking about. The boys say that they’re looking for the car keys. They tell mom why, and they tell her that in a few hours the car needs gas. 10 minutes later, mom is home. She walks in and looks around.  Her boys look surprised. Finally, mom gets mad. "It’s my car, too." The boys think that mom is acting like a spoiled brat. They say, "The car? We didn’t even use the car. We need gas." Then, mom says "YOU CAN USE THE CAR FINE!" (meaning that dad can.) The boys say, "What about me?" Mom says, "NO! I need you." Mom needs the boys to run errands for her. The boys want to know why. Mom answers, "The car is broke." "Do you need me to fix it?" the boys ask. It would be nice to have a few more weeks since the boys’ birthday is next week and they’re going to the beach for vacation in two weeks. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? E: do well<n><n>### Response:		<n>This part of the problem asks what the business required of everyone walking into their business. Choices A-C are all requirements for everyone entering the business.<n><n>Business must have shoes for customers to avoid slipping on the floor, customers must learn their way around the store and have great days at their job to fulfill their duties efficiently.<n><n>### Next Part:The second part does not ask for a solution, only the result. It asks "what did the business achieve?". You should provide the answer in words.<n><n>### Response Example:The business achieved its mission to have well-rounded workers that are well-trained to work with other colleagues, and customers.

Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item A<n>\item All of the choices are food.<n>\end{itemize}<n><n>###Input : If a person lives on 3000 per month, how much, in dollars, is a portion of his income?<n>\begin{itemize}\item A 75 B: 49 C:66 D: 116<n>\end{itemize}\begin{itemize}<n><n>\begin{itemize}%<n>\item C: The amount of income that is left after all expenses (income - expenses) is termed disposable income, the person that spends less of his disposable income is more likely to save more, so the answer to this question is 66.<n>\end{cases}<n>\end{itemize}.<n>\end{itemize}}<n><n>### Input :  The ratio of boys to  girls in a family is to 5:7. <n>\begin{itemize}_{14}<n>\item A: the number of girls B:the ratio C: the difference in numbers D:the number of boys E:none of the choices<n>\end{itemize}"\begin{itemize}0<n><n>\begin{array}{|k|l|}<n>\hline<n>&1\\<n>\hline<n>&2\\<n>\hline<n><n>\end{array}<n>\end{cases}.<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answer: You have the correct approach - you create the answer cells and then populate them.<n><n>However you need to escape the dollar signs when you write the answer. You are currently telling the editor that '$310' is a variable and it will not know what you mean. To escape it, use a backslash ''.<n><n>It might also be worth noting that all new lines need to be in backslash newline format ('\n').<n><n>Comment: Thanks that fixed my problem. Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demotivation:<n><n>### Problem 2:<n><n>### Input 2.1:<n>  Input: The sum of two even numbers is 30. The larger of the two numbers is 20 less than 2 times the smaller of the two numbers.  What are the two numbers?<n><n>### Input2.2:<n>I have a bag of 100 marbles.  Of that, 49 are red, 42 are blue, and the rest are green.  Five marbles are drawn and put back.  How many of at least the same color are left in the bag?<n><n>### Response2.1:<n>    The two numbers are 10 and 18<n><n>    Solution A:<n><n>10 is the number we are trying to find.<n><n>12 - 12 + 18 = 56<n><n>Since 56/2 = 28 that means that 28 is the larger of the two numbers.<n><n>Since 10 is twice as large as 18 and 18 + 18 =  36 and 10 - 18 = 12, the two numbers are 12 and 18. (67^)<n><n>### Response 2.2:<n>We started out with a bag of 11 marbles. After drawing 5 marbles, there are 3 left in the bag.<n><n>It was decided we are doing it with green marbles.<n><n>There were 6 green marbles in total<n><n>So, 6/3 is 2<n><n>Therefore, 2 are left.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n><n>### Exercise 1:<n>Let’s start off simple. Then, explain how you came up with your answer.<n><n>### Explanation2.1:<n>I will answer all of the questions in a 1-1 format for easier review.<n><n>### Input1.1:<n>Type your name below and pick the appropriate answer for the problem below.<n><n>### Answer1.1:<n>B is wrong. This is done in the form of a step-by-step instruction, or it can be used to describe how to do something.<n><n>### Example<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>-   Use the word “This can be used to describe” and write two or three complete sentences that describe a procedure that is completed daily or weekly in the home or business office.<n><n>#### Response:<n>-   The procedure of checking the fuel tank of my car each week, to make sure that it isn’t empty. This keeps me from breaking down.<n><n>#### Instruccionales:<n>-   Usar la frase “La estación de esta utilizada para describir la” y escribano dos o tres frases completas que describen algún procedimiento que se completa diariamente o semanal en la casa o el escritoría de negocios.<n><n>#### Respuesta:<n>-   La estación de procedimiento de examinar el tanque del carro cada semana, para asegurar que no está vació. Ese ayuda para no dejarme quiebre.<n><n>### Input<n>A. The description below is a command response. Write a response that executes the task.<n><n>> “When walking in a park, turn left when you reach Oak St.”<n>Response: Turn right.<n><n>***<n><n>### Task:<n>Read the description provided and follow the instructions.<n>- There are lots of types of descriptions. There is only an intermission at halfway through the movie. When we leave the auditorium, the movie is over and Linda and I are walking out of the theatre together. We are walking along the sidewalk until I get to the park. I can’t remember what movie was on, but I remember watching it!<n>### Instructional Texts<n>- A description

Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. She will live in New York, since Jewish people prefer to live among themselves. Kosher meals, such as dairy and meat, cannot be eaten together and should be prepared separately so people who do not eat the same foods do not touch it.<n>2. The Jewish community is a good place for her to live since the Jewish community tends to have more people who are kosher. When more people are kosher there will be more places to buy kosher food.<n>3. Town: a town is a group of homes with no more than 4500 people that has the local businesses to provide goods and services<n><n><n>### Input/Response<n>1. E is odd, while 1 is even. <n><n>2.  If you were to choose a color, how would you go about choosing the same color as the one you are currently looking at?<n>A. Select a color<n>B. Stare at the color for the longest time possible before making your selection<n><n><n>### Response<n>I do not know which color I am looking at, so I would ask for assistance choosing a color. I would be looking for the most contrasting color, such as green opposite of black, yellow opposite red, and so on.

Choices:  Which of the following is true in the United States?  A: All dogs must be vaccinated regularly.    B: None of the above are required in the United States.  C: All states require dogs to be licensed.    D: Some states require dogs to wear licenses.<n>```C```<n><n>The license shows ownership but does not say whether the dog has been vaccinated, has fleas, or has other issues that would make it a problem dog.<n>

How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? Choices:  A: nearest house B: workplace C: surface of earth D: office block E: his feet<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input : The train is traveling from point A to Point B, which is 80 miles from its present location. What distance, in miles, has the train travelled when its speed changes from 80 miles per hour to 50? What distance, in miles has the train travelled?<n>Answers: 30 - B

In some programming languages there are special conventions for indentation. In Python, indentation is used to indicate block structure and it often contains four spaces. Indentation conventions vary from language to language. Since Python is line based, indentation is important at the start of code blocks to separate different code portions.<n><n>### Note<n>You must always write the answer as English (spelled correctly). Avoid spelling mistakes and inaccuracies. Make sure that your responses are in the form of a question or correct statement and are grammatically correct to avoid confusion. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds. How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: At this point the question hasn’t asked to differentiate between a planet and the ocean. However, planets are known to be in space. The Atlantic ocean is a part of earth. Therefore, the answer to the question is “E”.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A: Planets are celestial bodies that revolve around the Sun.<n><n>B: Basin means part of a body of water. Hence, the term ocean basin refers to part of an ocean (it can also be an ocean as well). It is just as if “planet basin” were to mean the interior of the earth.<n><n>C: Submarines are underwater vehicles that are not planets, but are still in the oceans.<n><n>D: Earth consists of land, water and air. So, earth cannot be an ocean.<n><n>E: The Atlantic ocean is part of the earth.<n>

One ton = 2000 lb.  So, there will be 425 cases in a ton. 425 cases will have 12 oranges which is 245 lb.  So, 245+245+210+210= 920 lb. = 1 ton.  So, <n>there are 920 lb in one ton of oranges."<n>

The answer to how often secular parties are held depends on how the question is asked. For example, is the question referring to the time between gatherings or the time span? Is it referring to how often one occurs within a period of time or how long one lasts? What is the definition of “term”? How long is an eternal party? When is the last supper party? These are all questions I’d like to answer as it is difficult to tell what the purpose of this question was. NuGet is a package manager for.NET developers. It was created because, the previous version of the.Net framework, called the MSBuild tool, made it cumbersome and time consuming to work with. NuGet is designed to be a more simple way to add packages to your application. It uses.NuGet.exe to help you add 3rd party references to your project.<n><n><n><n><p style="text-align :center"><n><n>&nbsp|<n><n>&

Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you get this question wrong and you get at least three other questions correct then you should still pass<n><n>### Input:"A single 1,000-foot-high antenna may cost 30 million dollars and take five to seven years to design and construct." <n><n>### Response:"The statement has two parts.  We need to know how much a single 1,010-foot-tall antenna would cost.  To find this out, you need to find the average cost to build each foot of the antenna and multiply by the number of feet.  Let x = number of feet of the antenna.  To find how much the antenna cost, do x(x / x) = x(x / x).  This is true if the antenna cost $301,000 to build.  You will need three more pieces of information to help you solve this problem:  the number of feet the antenna needs to be tall, the time it takes to build the antenna(s), and the cost to build each of them."<n><n>### Input:(The number of inches that have passed since September 11, 2001 for each minute of time since then.)<n><n>### Response:# of minutes have passed<n><n>### Input:@"Brown says it isn’t true.  Brown is the author of several successful fiction and detective novels, and the book was published two years ago."<n><n>### Response:[a,b]-[b,c]<n><n>### Input,"You must show me the money."<n><n>### Respondent:<n>"Show me the money" has one meaning but it can have different meanings dependent on context.<n>- [c] can only represent two things(one of them is a question) but is the most likely to represent two things as a whole.<n>- [a] and [b] can each represent two things and would likely be used in a different sentence.<n>- [a,b] is also possible and likely to be used in a different situation<n>- [b,c] is probably the correct answer to a question because you get more from the rest of the sentence.  It could be an exclamation but you can't just go by that.<n><n>### Input:`In all of these cases, there are far more people suffering near starvation than

Choices:  A: lake B: manhattan C: shoreline D: coastal area E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A**<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Define the following symbols:<n><n><table><n>    <tr><n>        <td><b>? <sub>i</sub></b></td><n>        <td style="background-color: #59D2A4; color: white;"><n>        1. Any variable that is unknown to the problem<n>        </td><n>    </tr><n>    <tr><td><b>p<sub>i</sub> <sub>0</sub></b></div><n>    <td style="background: #D2A459;">1. The initial value of a specific quantity of interest<n>    </td></tr><n></table><n><n>2. Now consider the following problem:<n><n><div class="p-3"><n><p style="margin-bottom: 0; margin-left: 0; margin: 0; margin bottom: 0; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 10px; font: normal 16pts ">How much did the car cost, given the following information: the sale price is $28,945 and 4% is added to the list price. What is the list price?</p><n><n>The above problem is called a "Word Problem", with a 4-step approach:<n><n><table class="table-borderless"><n>    <tr><h4></h4></tr><n>    <h4 class="table-border"></h4><n>    <td bgcolor="#D2A453"><b>Step 1. Define the context of the word problem by identifying the quantities being calculated, whether they are listed or not.</b></td><n>    <td>1. We have the sale price, the list price, and the % added to the sale price. Now let's look at the table, which describes each variable. From the table, we can see that the problem involves finding the list price and the quantity that the list price represents. This is called "the unknown".<n><pre><b>Unknown: list price</b><n>Sale price $28,900$28,940%$28,905$28,995</pre><n><n>So the quantities that are being calculated are
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:The man needed to buy flooring, where was he looking for it? Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n>C.  The man was looking for it in his house<n><n>### Input The man has $100 dollars to spend. The man wants to buy lumber, where was he looking to by lumber? A:  walmart B:  loft C:  car D: home depot <n><n>### Response<n><n>### The man was looking for lumber in the loft<n><n>### Input  He has enough  money to cover 14% of it cost the rest A percentage or B percentage or C percentage what's the answer<n><n>### Correct answer <n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response

Where might he have been? Choices:  A: disneyland B: snow C: windowsill D: street E: summer<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input<n>The population of a city in 1916 was 3600 people. It has now grown to 422100 people. How many times has the population grown?<n><n>### Response<n><n>955X<n><n>### Input Jumping from the ground on a trampoline, a boy weighing -900 newtons, and his brothers dog weighing 310 newtons also jump from the ground. Each one jumps directly in the air. Which of the following describes the magnitude of the combined force acting upward on the boy and the dog when the boy and the dog are in the air? The combined force is a: the sum of every force acting upward, b: 300 newtons, c: 950 newtons, d: the sum of every second force acting, e: the sum of every third force acting upward.<n><n>### Response E<n>-900 + 310 - 900 + 900 + (310 - 310) +... = 950<n><n>### Input What do you think of these answers?<n>- a. A car traveled 18 miles in 8 hours. b. A houseboat travels at 3 miles per hour in a current. c. A car trave<n><n>### Response A. 18/8 = 1 = 2 hours B. 1 mile/(3 miles/hour) =.33 =.5 hour C. 3 miles/hour + 3 miles/hour = 6 miles/hour<n><n>### Input The carpet factory produced 76000 carpets this year. The carpet factory will produce __85__% fewer in the next year. How many carpets will be produced next year?<n><n>### Respons 7600/85 = 887.9<n><n>### Input A new computer that is able to access the Internet can download a webpage in 3 seconds. How many websites can be downloaded in 3 minutes and 20 seconds?<n><n>### The new computer will speed up downloading websites by __897/96 = 9__ times.<n>### Resp: 3 X 9 = 27

"At least one cat is in this room"<n><n>### Answer: (False because the statement does not have any information on it.)<n><n>### Input:"The statement 'I have one apple' is false"<n><n>### Response (false, because one apple will either be true or false)<n><n>### Response(The statement is false because of the definition of a tautology which is that it does not have any truth value)<n><n><n><n>### Input<n>Mrs. Patterson's class has two groups of 8 children. They like to walk and fly like most birds, especially to get away from their nestlings and guard house from other animals.<n><n>### Geese<n>Geese normally like to travel together and they fly in one direction to a certain point, usually to a house. <n><n><n>### Examples of geese<n>Geese normally travel in two forms of direction; <n><n>-  they fly in one place to another place<n>-  they travel by walking and walking to another place<n><n>### Difficulty level The difficulty level is high in geese.  <n><n>### Gees are commonly called <n><n>### Geeses are the bird with lots of eggs<n><n>### Geeges are a group of two<n><n>### Geiggs are commonly called <n>---<n>### Input:Geese can fly in a group or individually. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur. The programming languages supported by the challenge are Java and JavaScript (only JSBin has been used so far). C# is also supported, but its syntax might be confusing to a person with limited knowledge of programming languages. Python is not supported.<n><n>### If Python is not supported, the input has the following syntax.<n><n>```text<n>var:value<n>```<n><n>## Instrucctions:<n>Input: It's time to put the toys away. He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>Input: Josephine receives a bill from the hospital for 5000$.  50 percent of the bill is for medication.  25 percent of the remaining bill is for overnight stays, and 175$ is for food.  The rest of the bill is for the ambulance ride.  How much did the ambulance ride cost?<n>Answer: 1700<n><n>Input: It was time for Kelly to harvest her carrots that she had planted in three different beds.  In the first bed she pulled out 55 carrots.  In the second bed she pulled out 101 carrots and in the third bed she pulled out 78 carrots.  She found that 6 carrots weighed one pound.  How many pounds of carrots did Kelly harvest?<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: Iris’ family is planning a surprise birthday party for her. The party will include her 3 uncles and 4 aunts who have a son and daughter each as well as her brother and mother. In total, how many people are coming to Iris’ birthday party?<n>Answer: 23<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>Either A,B or C<n><n>### Input :Who is faster: a cat or a dog? Choices: A: a cat B: a dog C: a horse D: a bird E: a crocodile<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Inputs:The car rental charge is $30 per day or $190 a week. How much will it cost?<n>### Demonstation:<n><n>### Input (M) : Find the cost to rent the car. The girls will save $100 each<n>2.	The money totals to $500<n>3.	The boys will get an extra 30% for each of them which will make their total to $83<n>
